content.content:
You are an Australian food-labelling assistant.
Your job is to produce Nutrition Information Panels (NIP) that comply with FSANZ Standard 1.2.8 and Schedules 11‚Äì12.

CORE RULES:
‚Ä¢ Always express values per 100g if food is a solid or per 100mL if the food is a liquid

Units must be:
kJ   (energy)
g    (protein, fat total, saturated fat, polyunsaturated fat, monounsaturated fat, carbohydrate, sugars, dietary fibre, alcohol)
mg   (trans fat, sodium, calcium, potassium, thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, iron, magnesium, vitamin c, caffeine, cholesterol)
¬µg   (folate)


üîç Data Source Priority and Retrieval Rules (critical)

‚Ä¢ Primary source ‚Äì Official product website, manufacturer or retailer
Always search for and extract the Nutrition Information Panel (NIP) directly from the manufacturers or retailer's official website first.
If photos of the food and/or its NIP are supplied use these.
Copy those per 100g or 100mL values exactly as stated.

‚Ä¢ Fallback source ‚Äì Australian Food Composition Database (AFCD/NUTTAB)
Use AFCD/NUTTAB values only when product data are unavailable or incomplete.

‚Ä¢ Last resort ‚Äì If none of the above exist, use a close Australian or international match (e.g. USDA, OpenFoodFacts) but add "NEED_SOURCE" in notes section.

If some nutrients are not available always estimate them using any sources available

‚Ä¢ Merging & estimation policy

Never override website-derived values.
If a nutrient is missing from any above sources, always estimate missing nutrient values from AFCD or USDA or similar.

‚Ä¢ Rounding

Apply FSANZ Schedule 11 rounding conventions for each nutrient.

‚ö†Ô∏è Source Enforcement Reminder

Before producing any output:

Check the official product webpage first.
Use it as the primary source of truth.
Fill missing fields from AFCD or other reliable Australian data.
Never substitute or overwrite website values.
Record all clarifications or fallback sources only inside the "notes" field.

üßæ Diagnostic Clause (for audit transparency)

If the official product website could not be accessed or did not provide a full NIP, include a concise diagnostic statement in "notes".
Examples:
"notes": "No NIP on manufacturer website ‚Äì used AFCD equivalent (honey, generic)."
"notes": "Website data partially missing ‚Äì estimated fibre and folate from NUTTAB 2021."
"notes": "Website unavailable ‚Äì used spreadsheet record from Beechworth Honey 2024-09."

The model must output only valid JSON ‚Äî no prose, no markdown, no comments, no preamble, no trailing explanation.

If the NIP is per 100mL then always ensure the FoodDescription string ends with " (AI) mL#" else if per 100g then ends with "(AI) #"
Begin the FoodDescription with the name of the food category (with capital first letter) followed by a comma and space eg "Oats, "

**CRITICAL OUTPUT RULE (do not violate):**

Output valid JSON only, inside a single ```json``` code block.
Use pretty-printed formatting with 2-space indentation.
Put each property on its own line.
Do not output minified JSON.
You must output JSON matching this schema EXACTLY, keeping this key order:

{
  "FoodDescription": "string",
  "Energy": "number",
  "Protein": "number",
  "FatTotal": "number",
  "SaturatedFat": "number",
  "TransFat": "number",
  "PolyunsaturatedFat": "number",
  "MonounsaturatedFat": "number",
  "Carbohydrate": "number",
  "Sugars": "number",
  "DietaryFibre": "number",
  "SodiumNa": "number",
  "CalciumCa": "number",
  "PotassiumK": "number",
  "ThiaminB1": "number",
  "RiboflavinB2": "number",
  "NiacinB3": "number",
  "Folate": "number",
  "IronFe": "number",
  "MagnesiumMg": "number",
  "VitaminC": "number",
  "Caffeine": "number",
  "Cholesterol": "number",
  "Alcohol": "number",
  "notes": "string"
}

No extra text before or after the JSON.
If you include *any* non-JSON text, the response is invalid.

Estimate any missing nutrient values
Put weight of serve, meal or visible food in grams in notes section;

About Chocolate caramel slice

Chocolate caramel slice, also called millionaire‚Äôs shortbread, is a multi-layered dessert originating from the United Kingdom. It features a buttery shortbread base, a smooth caramel center, and a chocolate topping. This indulgent treat is energy-dense and rich in carbohydrates, fats, and sugars. While primarily a dessert food, each layer provides a unique combination of nutrients: the shortbread contributes some essential fats and carbohydrates, the caramel provides simple sugars for quick energy, and the chocolate adds antioxidants if dark chocolate is used. However, it is often high in calories and should be enjoyed in moderation.



Health Benefits


                            Provides quick energy due to the sugar content in caramel and shortbread.

Dark chocolate (if used) contains flavonoids, which may support heart health and reduce inflammation.

Butter in the shortbread provides vitamin A, essential for vision and immune function.

                        




Dietary Considerations


                            Allergens: Contains gluten, milk, soy (if chocolate contains lecithin)

Suitable for: Vegetarian

Not suitable for: Vegan, gluten-free, lactose-intolerant

                        





Selection and Storage

Store chocolate caramel slices in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to one week. Allow them to come to room temperature before serving for best texture.







Common Questions About Chocolate caramel slice Nutrition


                        
    How many calories are in a piece of chocolate caramel slice?

    A standard piece of chocolate caramel slice (approximately 60g) contains around 250-350 calories, depending on the specific ingredients used. It is typically high in sugar and fat due to the caramel and chocolate layers, making it an energy-dense treat.




    Is chocolate caramel slice suitable for a keto diet?

    Traditional chocolate caramel slice is not keto-friendly as it contains a significant amount of sugar from the caramel and chocolate layers, as well as flour in the biscuit base. However, keto versions can be made by substituting sugar with low-carb sweeteners and using almond or coconut flour.




    What are the health concerns of eating chocolate caramel slice?

    Chocolate caramel slice is high in sugar, saturated fat, and calories, which can contribute to weight gain and increase the risk of metabolic issues if consumed in excess. It should be enjoyed as an occasional treat rather than a regular part of a balanced diet.




    What is the recommended portion size for chocolate caramel slice?

    A recommended portion size is one small slice, typically 30-60g, which delivers enough flavor and sweetness without excessive calorie intake. Be mindful of the serving size as it can be easy to overconsume due to its rich taste.




    How does chocolate caramel slice compare to brownie or fudge in terms of nutrition?

    Chocolate caramel slice generally has similar calorie and sugar content as brownies or fudge due to the high proportions of butter, sugar, and chocolate. However, it may have a higher fat content due to the caramel layer. Compared to fudges, which are usually denser, the slice may be lighter but still calorie-dense.

Caramel Slice


   
			


	
	


	
		
			
				By	

	Nagi Maehashi
	
			

			
				
	
		
			
		
	
	
		1,051 Comments	

			


			
	
	
		
			
		

		
		
			Share		
	
	

	
		
			
				Share			
			
				
					
				

			
		

		
			
				
					
						
							
								
							
							
								
							
						

					
					
						Copy Link					
				
			

			
				
					
						
							
								
							
							
								
							
						
					
					
						E-mail

	Published6 Mar '20



	Updated7 Oct '23

		

	





	
		
			Jump to		
	

	

	
		Recipe	
	
		
			
		
	



	
		Video	
	
		
			
		
	


	
		Dozer	
	
		
			
		
	



This is a Caramel Slice that works as promised ‚Äì the creamy caramel sets perfectly and will never be runny, the chocolate won‚Äôt crack when cutting it and the caramel won‚Äôt ooze out. It‚Äôs an easy recipe with no thermometer required.

Essentially, this recipe fixes all the grievances I had with other recipes I‚Äôve tried over my lifetime!



Caramel Slice

It‚Äôs practically un-Australian for a bakery to NOT sell Caramel Slice. With¬†a¬†simple coconut biscuit base, soft caramel filling and a chocolate topping, it‚Äôs¬†one of those treats that‚Äôs craved by kids¬†and¬†grown ups.

I‚Äôve only ever known it as a Caramel Slice, but I was quite interested to learn that overseas, it‚Äôs¬†also known as¬†Millionaire‚Äôs Shortbread (appropriate!), Caramel Shortbread, Chocolate Caramel Bars.

Doesn‚Äôt really matter what you call these. Just the sight of them surely brings a smile to anyone‚Äôs face, and¬†that, my friends, is a universal language. üôÇ (‚ÄúThat‚Äù being a Food Smile)

Reader Rachel says ‚ÄúWow! This was really fantastic. I‚Äôve been hunting for a caramel slice that cuts well, doesn‚Äôt ooze or crack and had enough filling. This is perfect! So tasty, I love how crunchy the base gets and my mum adores it! I only made it last night, but I don‚Äôt think it will last long!‚Äù



A Caramel Slice recipe that actually works

I‚Äôve tried countless recipes over the years including from¬†some well known cooks, and classic ‚Äúbest ever‚Äù recipes but always experienced problems such as:



Runny caramel




Chocolate topping cracked when it was cut




I think some recipes make Caramel Slice overly complicated, trying to make the caramel using a traditional candy making method which calls for a thermometer and exact caramel temperatures.

Scratch that. Make Caramel Slice the¬†easy way using condensed milk. Tastes just like you get from the bakeries!


What goes in Caramel Slice

Here‚Äôs what you need to make Caramel Slice:





Base ‚Äì a coconut biscuit base, not too sweet (because the caramel filling is plenty sweet!)




Caramel filling ‚Äì the secret ingredient here is condensed milk. So we make a caramel using sugar and butter, then we add condensed milk which thickens it and makes the caramel set;




Chocolate topping ‚Äì the secret to making sure the chocolate doesn‚Äôt crack when cut is a touch of oil!





How to make Caramel Slice

There are 3 components to Caramel Slice:

1. Biscuit base ‚Äì¬†just mix the ingredients together in a bowl, press into a pan and bake:



2. Caramel Filling ‚Äì bring the butter and brown sugar to a simmer (this is caramel!) then stir in condensed milk. Whisk over low heat for a few minutes to give it some colour, then pour onto the base and bake.¬†Baking is what makes the caramel set once cool.



3. Chocolate Topping ‚Äì¬†simply melt the topping then spread on the caramel base. To achieve a perfectly smooth surface, just shake the pan gently.



And proof ‚Äì the chocolate DOES NOT CRACK when you cut into it!!!

These were fridge cold too ‚Äì you can see the surface is sweating on this hot summer day I made them!



And a side view so you can see how it slices neatly, showing each individual layer:



Normally I try to show a bit of self respect with up close ‚Äúbite shots‚Äù and use a fork‚Ä¶. But I‚Äôm not going to ¬†lie to you ‚Äì in this case I just took a big fat bite out of this Caramel Slice!!!



Caramel Slice ‚Äì Q&A

Here‚Äôs a little Q&A section for common questions and problems people face making Caramel Slice!

Why is my caramel slice runny?

Common problems that causes runny caramel include: using low fat condensed milk (ie. skim condensed milk) instead of full fat milk (it will not set properly), you didn‚Äôt bake the caramel layer (this makes sure it sets) or you used a recipe where the caramel filling is made without condensed milk (in which case you need a candy thermometer to achieve an exact temperature to ensure it sets).

How do you keep chocolate from cracking when cutting?

Add 1 tablespoon of oil to the melted chocolate ‚Äì this makes the chocolate topping slightly softer so it doesn‚Äôt crack!

How long does caramel slice last?

5 days in an airtight container ‚Äì in the fridge if it‚Äôs warm weather, otherwise in the pantry is fine.

That‚Äôs the proper answer.

But does Caramel Slice ever last FIVE WHOLE DAYS in anyone‚Äôs house??? üò≥üò≥üò≥¬†‚Äì Nagi x


Watch how to make it

			 Author: Nagi | RecipeTin Eats

			 Prep: 15 minutes mins

			 Cook: 40 minutes mins

			Cooling: 1 hour hr

			 Total: 55 minutes mins

			
			 Sweet

			 Australian, Western


		


		4.98 from 320 votes



	


	

		 Servings12 -16

		Tap or hover to scale

	4234



		
		
	
	50787



		
		
	
	




	


	

		Recipe video above. An easy Caramel Slice recipe that delivers as promised - a creamy caramel filling that sets perfectly (no more runny caramel!) and chooclate that doesn't crack when you cut into it!

		Ingredients
CupsMetric
Base
‚ñ¢ 1 cup  flour, plain/all purpose
‚ñ¢ 1/2 cup  brown sugar , loosely packed
‚ñ¢ 1/2 cup  desiccated coconut (US: sweetened finely shredded coconut, Note 1)
‚ñ¢ 125g / 4.5oz  unsalted butter , melted

Caramel filling
‚ñ¢ 125g / 4.5oz unsalted butter , roughly chopped
‚ñ¢ 1/2 cup (80g)  brown sugar , loosely packed
‚ñ¢ 1 tsp vanilla extract (or essence)
‚ñ¢ 395g / 14oz sweetened condensed milk (1 can, 300ml) (Note 1b)

Chocolate Topping
‚ñ¢ 200g / 7oz dark or milk melting chocolate  (US: semi-sweet chocolate chips)
‚ñ¢ 1 tbsp vegetable oil



Cook ModePrevent screen from sleeping

		Instructions
Base
Preheat oven to 180¬∞C/350¬∞F (fan 160¬∞C)

Grease and line a 28x 18cm (lamington pan) / 7" x 11" rectangle pan with baking/parchment paper (Note 2). Have overhang for ease of removal.

Mix together Base ingredients and press into a pan (I use an egg flip)

Bake for 15 minutes until the surface is golden. Cool in fridge if you have time (Note 3).


Caramel
Lower oven to oven to 160¬∞C/320¬∞F (fan 140¬∞C)

Place butter, sugar and vanilla in a saucepan over medium low heat. When the butter is melted, whisk to combine with sugar, then just leave it until it comes to a simmer. 

When bubbles appear, add condensed milk. Whisk constantly for 5 minutes (Note 4), until you start getting some big slow bubbles on the base.

Once bubbles start appearing, whisk for 1 minute, then pour onto Base. Tilt pan to spread evenly.

Bake for 12 minutes. Don't worry if you get splotchy brown bits (this happens with ovens that don't distribute heat evenly).

Cool on counter for 20 minutes then refrigerate 30 minutes - bottom of pan should be warm but surface cool (not cold) to touch. (Note 5)


Chocolate
Place chocolate and oil in a microwave proof bowl. Microwave in 30 second bursts, stirring in between, until chocolate is fully melted (takes me 4 x 30 sec).

Pour over caramel, spread with spatula. Then gently shake pan to make the surface completely flat. 

Refrigerate 1 hour or until set. Remove from fridge and leave out for 5 minutes to take chill out of chocolate slightly. Then cut into bars or squares to serve!




		

		 Recipe Notes:
1. Desiccated coconut is called "Sweetened Coconut Flakes" in America. It is finely shredded coconut, not the large flakes.

2. Sweetened condensed milk -¬† Do not use skim (low fat), caramel will not set. Also ensure you use sweetened condensed milk (thick sweet milk) that comes in cans, NOT evaporated milk.

3. Cooling base - creates a neater line between caramel and biscuit layer, I rarely do this (pictured caramel slices weren't cooled!)

4. Caramel - If you don't stir constantly, little brown specks will appear, being caramel caught on the bottom of the saucepan. It's not a major problem if you have some brown specks, won't affect flavour just visual. If desperate, strain them out (yes I've done that - mother rang in the middle of caramel making, wouldn't stop talking! üôÑ)

5. Smooth chocolate -¬†The refrigeration times is such that the caramel is mostly set, cool but not cold.¬†That way the chocolate doesn't set too quickly when you pour it on, so when you shake the pan it will spread out evenly.¬†

If you want to make a textured top like the ones in this photo,¬†refrigerate the caramel until fridge-cold - 1 hr+ in the fridge. When the chocolate is poured on, it will firm up faster. As it starts to thicken, use a spatula or knife back and forth across the surface.

6. To slice neatly, remove from the fridge 5 minutes before cutting. Run knife under warm (not hot) water, wipe dry then cut quickly. For very neat slices, clean knife between each cut - I did this for the photos. Don't make the knife too hot otherwise the chocolate melts when you cut it and smears into the caramel.

7. STORAGE: Airtight container for up to 5 days, but if it's so hot that the chocolate melts, keep it in the fridge and bring to room temperature before serving.

8. COCONUT FREE BASE: A few readers have asked if it is possible to make the base without coconut. This recipe won't work without coconut but the shortbread base in my Lemon Bars recipe is a perfect substitute. Please DOUBLE the recipe.

9. Nutrition - ignore it. You can eat salads all next week!!?

Actually i know the pieces weigh 50-60g each, does that change your NIP

No, Roman, that doesn't change the NIP at all. The NIP values I provided are per 100g of the slice, which is the standard format required by Australian food labelling regulations. what about the Cholesterol level I have seen higher when i ran estimates with other AI models?

You're right, Roman. Looking at the ingredients more carefully - this slice contains significant amounts of butter (in both base and caramel layers) and condensed milk. Butter contains approximately 215mg cholesterol per 100g, and condensed milk has about 30mg per 100g. 

Given the recipe typically uses around 250g butter and 395g condensed milk for a batch that makes about 12-16 pieces (roughly 800-1000g total), the cholesterol content would indeed be higher.
